turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: And his staff.  Come on, the copy they were filing from China was great.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Wait till the Mai-tais wear off.

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: The Jews aren't the middle, Henry. They're the far left.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You're talking too much about black Africa, Henry.  It's killing us with the rednecks.

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: The blacks are lost, the "schwartzes" are gone ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Don't let it lose us the right-wing vote ...

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: Gentlemen, I think it's about time for us to be getting to the airport.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Let him finish, Bob.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You know, they all miss the point. Probably our biggest achievement as an administration, when it's all said and done, isn't China or Russia.  It's pulling out of Vietnam without a right wing revolt.

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: I believe you're right, boss.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: ... but even the presidency isn't enough anymore ...

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: The presidency won't protect us, Bob. We're beyond politics now ...

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: Congratulations, boss.  A great victory!  The madman theory wasn't so crazy after all.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: This could be it ... this could be it. Four long years ...

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: So that explains his press notices. Working both sides of the fence: Jewboy Henry, always trying to get his Nobel Prize, get laid ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: My God, my God!  He talked to the New York Times?

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: We ought to fire his whining ass. Right now when he's on top.  You know what -- it'll set the right example for the rest of this administration.

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: Because they're not Americans.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Right.  They don't trust!  They don't trust America!

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: Why would they?!  Who the hell's Sulzberger anyway?  Their parents are gold traders from Eastern Europe. They buy things.  They come to Jew York City and they buy up things.  One of the things they buy is the New York Times.  And you know what?  Be proud because they'll never trust you, sir, because we speak for the average American.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You know why they're turning on me? They're not serious about power, that's why.  They're playing with power.  They're forgetting the national interest.  In the old days, people knew how to hold power, how to set limits.  They wouldn't have torn this country apart over a third-rate burglary. All they care about now are their egos, looking good at cocktail parties ...

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: ... beating out the other papers, chasing girls ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: ... worrying whether someone said something "nice" about them.  All short-term, frivolous bullshit; Ben Bradlee worrying about Teddy Kennedy liking him ...

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: You played it perfectly, sir -- cocksucker!  He's going to think twice before he leaks again.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: He'll be looking in his toilet bowl every time he pulls the chain.

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: We've got to turn the faucet off on this thing.  It's out of control ...  You might burden just me with this in the future.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: It's Helms -- it's got to be.

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: We could leverage Helms.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: When I met with him, he said ...

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: ... I was wondering what's such dynamite in this Bay of Pigs story?  ... although it was clearly effective, because all of a sudden it was no problem for Helms to go to the FBI and try to put a lid on Watergate.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: What about the documents he promised?

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: He'll give us the documents.  But I think he should be offered the ambassadorship to Iran.  Then he'll go without a whimper.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I promised Iran to Townsend.

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: Put Townsend in Belgium; it's available.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Townsend gave us 300 grand.  Belgium's not worth more than 100, 150 ...

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: Helms wants Iran or there might be problems.  All of his old CIA buddies are over there making a fortune off the Shah.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: For God's sake, when does this end?!

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: More light, chief?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: No ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: ... There can be no whitewash at the White House ... two wrongs do not make a right.  I love America.  God bless America and God bless each and every one of you.

turns.speaker: HALDEMAN
turns.text: Sir ... six bodies.

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: Richard ... come with me, would you ...

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Why me?

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: Because Harold tests thy father's will is no reason to admire him.  Let Harold's worldliness be a warning to thee, not an example.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Yes, Mother ...

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: Harold may have lost touch with his Bible, but thou must never lapse.

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: Do not tell a lie, Richard ... The cornsilk cigarette Harold gave thee behind the store this morning.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: I don't ... have them.  Mother ... I swear, I ... didn't smoke.

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: I see ... Well then, Richard, we have nothing more to talk about, do we?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Please, Mother, it ... it was just one time, Mother, I'm ... I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: So am I.  Thy father will have to know of thy lying.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: No, no!  Please, don't.  Don't tell him.  I'll never do it again.  I promise.  I promise ...  Please, mama ...

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: I expect more from thee, Richard.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Please!  I'll never let you down again, Mother.  Never.  I promise.

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: Then this shall be our little secret.  Remember that I see into thy soul as God sees.  Thou may fool the world. Even thy father.  But not me, Richard. Never me.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Mother, think of me always as your faithful dog ...

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: We haven't said grace yet.  Richard.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Is it my turn?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: I can't ...

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: Thou must.

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: It's a gift, Richard.  This law school is a gift from your brother.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Did he have to die for me to get it?!

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: It's meant to make us stronger.  Thou art stronger than Harold ... stronger than Arthur.  God has chosen thee to survive ...

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: What about happiness, Mother?

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: Thou must find thy peace at the center, Richard.  Strength in this life.  Happiness in the next.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: What'd he say?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What do you think?  He said in life there's no free ride.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: What'd you say?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I said I didn't need a free ride.  I need a suit.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Oh, no, Harold.  He doesn't respond well to humor.  Maybe if you talk to Mother she can ...

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'd rather get a whipping than have another talk with her.  Anything but a talk with her.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Hey ... you'll be able to do it now.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: What ... ?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Go to law school.  Mom and Dad'll be able to afford it now ...

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Mom expects great things from you ...

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Harold ... can I get you anything?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Relax, Dick, it's just me ... The desert's so beautiful, isn't it?  I want to go home, Dick.  Time to go home.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: You're not gonna quit on me, are you, Harold?

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: I'm honored, Dick, that you've come all this way out here to Virginia to visit us at last.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: My friends call me "Mister President."

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: And so shall I.  Arrange some coffee, would you General Cushman?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Robert Cushman is a lieutenant general in the Marine Corps, the Deputy Director of the CIA ... and this is what you use him for?

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: I didn't choose him as my deputy, Mr. President.  You did.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: I suppose, "Mister President," you're unhappy that we have not implemented your Domestic Intelligence plan, but ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You're correct.  I'm concerned these students are being funded by foreign interests, whether they know it or not.  The FBI is worthless in this area.  I want your full concentration on this matter ...

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: Of course we've tried, but so far we've come up with nothing that ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Then find something.  And I want these leaks stopped.  Jack fucking Anderson, the New York Times, the State Department -- I want to know who's talking to them.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: I'm sure you realize this is a very tricky area, Mr. President, given our charter and the congressional oversight committees ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Screw congressional oversight.  I know damn well, going back to the '50's, this agency reports what it wants, and buries what it doesn't want Congress to know.  Pay close attention to this.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: Is there something else that's bothering you, Mr. President?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yes ... It involves some old and forgotten papers.  Things I signed as Vice President.  I want the originals in my office and I don't want copies anywhere else.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: You're referring, of course, to chairing the Special Operations Group as Vice President.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yes ...

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: Diem?  Trujillo?  Lumumba?  Guatemala? Cuba? ... It's a shame you didn't take similar precautions, Dick.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I'm interested in the documents that put your people together with ... the others.  All of them ...

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: President Kennedy threatened to smash the CIA into a thousand pieces.  You could do the same ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I'm not Jack Kennedy.  Your agency is secure.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: Not if I give you all the cards ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I promised the American people peace with honor in Southeast Asia.  That could take time -- two, maybe three years ... In the meantime, your agency will continue at current levels of funding.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: Current levels may not be sufficient.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: The President would support a reasonable request for an increase.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: And me? ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Firing you, Mr. Helms, wouldn't do any good.  Of course you'll continue as DCI.  You're doing a magnificent job.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: And of course I accept.  I'm flattered.  And I want you to know, I work for only one president at a time.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yes.  And you will give General Cushman full access.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: It will take a little time, but I'll order a search for your papers. Though it does raise a disturbing issue.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: Mr. Castro.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: We have recent intelligence that a Soviet nuclear submarine has docked at Cienfuegos.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Well, we'll lodge a formal protest.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: I don't think we can treat this as a formality.  Mr. Kennedy made a verbal promise to the Russians not to invade Cuba.  But you authorized Dr. Kissinger to put this in writing.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Are you tapping Kissinger?

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: My job, unpleasant sometimes, is to know what others don't want me to know.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Not if you have spies in the White House, it isn't your job.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: It is not my practice to spy on the president.  Doctor Kissinger manages to convey his innermost secrets to the world at large on his own.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Mr. Helms, we've lived with Communism in Cuba for ten years ...

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: ... But it has never been the policy of this government to accept that. And it is certainly not CIA policy.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: CIA policy?  The CIA has no policy, Mr. Helms.  Except what I dictate to you ...  I try to adjust to the world as it is today, not as you or I wanted it to be ten years ago.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: Is that why you and Kissinger are negotiating with the Chinese?

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: This is an extremely dangerous direction, Mr. President.  Terrible consequences can result from such enormous errors in judgement.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: But ... if we were able to separate China from Russia once and for all, we can -- we could create a balance of power that would secure the peace into the next century.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: By offering Cuba to the Russians as a consolation prize?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Cuba would be a small price to pay.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: So President Kennedy thought.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I never thought Jack was ready for the presidency.  But I would never, never consider ...  His death was awful, an awful thing for this country.  Do you ever think of death, Mr. Helms?

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: Flowers are continual reminders of our mortality.  Do you appreciate flowers?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: No.  They make me sick.  They smell like death ... I had two brothers die young.  But let me tell you, there are worse things than death.  There is such a thing as evil.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: You must be familiar with my favorite poem by Yeats?  "The Second Coming"?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HELMS
turns.text: Black Irishman.  Very moving. "Turning and turning in the widening gyre / The falcon cannot hear the falconer / Things fall apart, the center cannot hold / Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world / And everywhere the ceremony of innocence is drowned / The best lack all conviction, while the worst are full of passionate intensity" ... But it ends so beautifully ominous -- "What rough beast, its hours come round at last / Slouches toward Bethlehem to be born?" ... Yes, this country stands at such a juncture.

turns.speaker: TOLSON
turns.text: What do you think this plan is, Edgar? A nuclear attack?

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: He's lying, Clyde.  Always has. That's why Nixon's always been useful. Hold still.  And take your hand off your hip.

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: I want to see him tomorrow, Clyde.

turns.speaker: TOLSON
turns.text: Edgar, think twice.  He works in the kitchen.

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: Not Joaquin, you idiot.  Nixon.  Did you hear what he said in Oregon? About me having too much power.

turns.speaker: TOLSON
turns.text: It's between Nixon and a Kennedy again, Edgar ... Who do you want?

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: Kennedy -- never.  He'll fry in hell for what he did to me.  But Nixon doesn't know that, which is why I'm gonna have to remind him he needs us a helluva lot more'n we need him.

turns.speaker: TOLSON
turns.text: ... little Bobby.

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: Would you walk with me down to the paddock?  I'd like to look at the horses for the eighth.

turns.speaker: TOLSON
turns.text: Ummm...

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: If things remain as they are ... He's got the anti-war vote.

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: It was the poorest lemon ranch in California, I can tell you that.  My father sold it before they found oil on it.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: It was the poorest lemon ranch in California, I can assure you.  My father sold it before they found oil on it.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: My father built the house where I was born with his own hands.  Oh, it wasn't a big house ...

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: Turn this crap off, Clyde.  It's giving me a headache ... You may go, Joaquin.

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: Thank you for coming, Dick.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Winning?

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: Actually, I've just had a bit of luck.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Oh, my goodness ...

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: How about you?  Are you going to win?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You should ask Bobby.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Can't we just talk here?  I've got the police chiefs in San Diego.

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: I'm trying to spare you an embarrassment.  Johnny Roselli is on his way back here.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Roselli?  Johnny Roselli?

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: Yes.  Your old friend from Cuba.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I never met the man.

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: I know you've been very careful not to.  That's why I'm concerned.

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: You'll win the nomination.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: It could be '60 all over again, Edgar. Bobby's got the magic, like a goddamn rock star.  They climb all over each other just to touch his clothes! He'll ride his brother's corpse right into the White House.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Or he'll steal it like his brother. He's a mean little sonofabitch, Edgar ... He had the IRS audit my mother when she was dying in a nursing home.

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: I know ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yeah, well, as I said, Edgar ...

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: You asked if you could count on my support ... As long as I can count on yours.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: The old queen did it on purpose.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: There must be a quarter-million out there, Edgar.  They've been at it now for a year.  Young kids just like Tricia.  I don't know.  Do you think they have a point, Edgar?  Maybe this whole damned system of government is ...

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: Remember what Lenin said in 1917, Mr. President: "The power was lying in the streets just waiting for someone to pick it up."  The Communists have never been closer.  Now is the time to go back to the old themes, the ones that made you president.  Let the Communists know you're onto them.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: The little bastards think they can ruin Tricia's wedding day by dancing naked in the Reflecting Pond.

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: Don't listen to 'em, don't quit. Remember - Kennedy, Bobby, and King were against the war.  Where are they now?  Don't give 'em a goddamn inch on the war.  President Johnson bombed Laos for years and nobody knew or said a thing.  How the hell the Times ever got ahold of this Ellsberg stuff is a disgrace!

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: We can't keep a goddamn secret in this government, Edgar.  They're stealing papers right out of his office.

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: Johnson had the same damned problem till he bugged his own office.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: We took his system out.

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: That was a mistake.  The White House was full of Kennedy people then.  It still is.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Who do you think is behind it?

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: Well, you have CIA people all over the place.  Helms has seen to that.  Then there's Kissinger's staff. Kissinger himself, I believe, maybe the leaker.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Kissinger?

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: He's obsessed with his own image.  He wants his Nobel Peace Prize a little too much.  As the late "Doctor" King proved -- even an ape can win a prize with good press.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Jesus, I'd like to book him into a psychiatrist's office.  He comes in here ranting and raving, dumping his crap all over the place ... Could you prove it, Edgar?

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: I always get my man.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yeah, you do.  I'd be bugging myself, Edgar ... Who'd get the tapes?

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: No one.  Your property.  It would prove your case.  Why do you think Kissinger's taping your calls?  For history.  His word against yours -- and right now he's got the records.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: This damned tie ... Will you help me, Edgar?  Churchill used to say to me, "If you want your own history written properly, you must write it yourself."  All right, Edgar, but just don't let it come back to haunt me.

turns.speaker: HOOVER
turns.text: It won't.  As long as I'm here.

turns.speaker: STURGIS
turns.text: How the fuck did you know?

turns.speaker: HUNT
turns.text: Injections.  Even this noble sport's been fixed.  Seen the guys?

turns.speaker: STURGIS
turns.text: They're around.

turns.speaker: STURGIS
turns.text: Why, you got a customer?

turns.speaker: HUNT
turns.text: The White House.

turns.speaker: STURGIS
turns.text: You're fucking me.

turns.speaker: HUNT
turns.text: We're gonna be plumbers, Frank.  We're gonna plug a leak.

turns.speaker: STURGIS
turns.text: Who we working for?

turns.speaker: HUNT
turns.text: A guy named Gordon Liddy.  Thinks he's Martin Borman.  You wanna meet him?

turns.speaker: STURGIS
turns.text: Where'd you find him?

turns.speaker: HUNT
turns.text: Just don't tell him to do anything you don't really want him to do.

turns.speaker: STURGIS
turns.text: So, does Tricky Dick know about this?

turns.speaker: HUNT
turns.text: I won't tell him if you won't.

turns.speaker: LIDDY
turns.text: Howard ... What the hell?  What're you doing?

turns.speaker: HUNT
turns.text: Dogs ... Season starts tomorrow.  It keeps me calm.  I don't like going back into the same building four times.

turns.speaker: HUNT
turns.text: Mein Kampf?

turns.speaker: LIDDY
turns.text: "A warrior with nerves of steel is yet broken by a thread of silk." Nietzsche.

turns.speaker: HUNT
turns.text: Personally I'd prefer a greyhound with a shot of speed.

turns.speaker: LIDDY
turns.text: Remember -- listen up!  Fire team discipline is there at all times. Keep your radios on at all times during the entire penetration.  Check yourselves.  Phony ID's, no wallets, no keys.  We rendezvous where?  The Watergate, Room 214.  When?  At zero three-hundred.

turns.speaker: HUNT
turns.text: Let's get the fuck out of here, shall we, ladies?

turns.speaker: LIDDY
turns.text: Anything goes wrong, head for your homes, just sit tight -- you'll hear from me or Howard.

turns.speaker: HUNT
turns.text: Personally, I'll be calling the President of the United States.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Thanks, Jack.  You sure throw a helluva party.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Party ain't started yet, Dick.  Got these gals coming over to the ranch later for a little private "thing," y'know ... There's some fellows I want you to meet.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Well, uh, Trini and I have an early plane.  We were hoping to get back to New York in time for ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Like you said Jack, I'm just a New York lawyer now.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: We'll see about that.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: I know for a fact that the one with the big tits is a Republican, and she'd do anything for the Party.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: She's quite pretty.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Her name's Sandy ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: By the way, Jack, this looks like a pretty straight-forward transaction to me, but we should get into it soon -- just take a few minutes, maybe up at the house ...

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: He's all business, ain't he, Trini?  Dick, we could've had our own goddamn lawyers handle this deal.  We brought you down here 'cause we wanted to talk to you ...

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Hell, Kennedy's pissed Cuba away to the Russians.  And he don't know what the hell he's doing in Vietnam.  These are dangerous times, Dick, especially for business ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Agreed.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Gentlemen, I tried.  I told Kennedy to go into Cuba.  He heard me and he made his decision.  I appreciate your sentiments.  I've heard them from many fine Cuban patriots, but it's nothing I can do anything about.  Now, it's a long drive back to Dallas tonight, and Trini and I have got an early flight tomorrow to New York ...

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Dick, these boys want you to run.  They're serious.  They can deliver the South and they can put Texas in your column.  That would've done it in '60.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Only if Kennedy dumps Johnson.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: That sonofabitch Kennedy is coming back down here tomorrow.  Dick, we're willing to put up a shitpot fulla money to get rid of him -- more money'n you ever dreamed of.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Nobody's gonna beat Kennedy in '64 with all the money in the world.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: So, what's this about, Dick?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: It's me or Wallace, Jack.  Wallace's third party is only going to help McGovern.  I need your support.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Well, you sure been chock full of surprises so far, "Mister President."

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: It looks like to me we're gonna lose the war for the first goddamned time and, Dick, goddamn it, you're going along with it, buying into this Kissinger bullshit -- "detente" with the Communists.  "Detente" -- it sounds like two fags dancing.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Jack, we're not living in the same country you and I knew in '46.  Our people are just not gonna sacrifice in major numbers for war.  We can't even get 'em to accept cuts in their gas tanks.  Hell, the Arabs and the Japanese are bleeding the shit out of our gold ..

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: And whose fault is that?  If we'd won in Vietnam ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: It's nobody's fault, Jack.  It's change -- which is a fact of history. Even that old cocksucker Hoover's dead.  Things change.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Desi's got a point.  What the hell are we gonna do about the Communists right here in our backyard?!

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: What do you mean, Jack?

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: I mean I got federal price controls on my oil.  The ragheads are beating the shit out of me.  And I got your EPA environment agency with its thumb so far up my ass it's scratching my ear.

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: ... And now I have a federal judge ordering me to bus my kids halfway 'cross town to go to school with some nigger kids. I think, Mr. President, you're forgetting who put you where you are.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: The American people put me where I am.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Because if you're uncomfortable with the EPA up your ass, try the IRS ...

turns.speaker: JONES
turns.text: Well, goddamn.  Are you threatening me, Dick?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Presidents don't threaten.  They don't have to.  Good day, gentlemen.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: Mr. President, we are in a revolutionary situation.  We are under siege -- Black Panthers, Weathermen; The State Department under Rogers is leaking like a sieve.  And now this insignificant little shit Ellsberg publishing all the diplomatic secrets of this country will destroy our ability to conduct foreign policy.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Here, Tim ... Tim.  I'm as frustrated as you, Henry, but don't you think this one's a Democrat problem.  They started the war; it makes them look bad.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Fuck it!  He doesn't like me, John!  It's your fault, Henry.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: I beg your pardon --

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: It's your people who are leaking to the Times.  Wasn't this Ellsberg a student of yours at Harvard?  He was your idea; why are you suddenly running for cover?

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: He was, he was.  We taught a class together at Harvard.  But you know these back-stabbing Ivy League intellectuals, they can't ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: No, Henry.  I don't.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: He's turned into a drug fiend, he shot people from helicopters in Vietnam, he has sexual relations with his wife in front of their children.  He sees a shrink in L.A.  He's all fucked up. Now he's trying to be a hero to the liberals ... If he gets away with it, everybody will follow his lead.  He must be stopped at all costs.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: Who are you talking to like this, you insignificant shit ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: ... and what do we get for it?  Gobs and gobs of bullshit, gossip, nothing! Someone is leaking. We've got to stop the leaks, Henry, at any cost, do you hear me?  Then we can go for the big play -- China, Russia.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Alright, Henry -- we're gonna go your way.  Crush this Ellsberg character the same way we did Hiss!

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: There's no other choice.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: We're gonna hit him so hard he looks like everything that's sick and evil about the Eastern Establishment.  You and your "plumbers" are gonna find dirt on this guy -- let's see him going to the bathroom in front of the American public!  And when we finish with him, they'll crucify him!

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: ... as the old alliances crumble.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: Finally someone who's noticed!  I'm a great admirer of yours, too, Mr. Nixon.  You are an unusual politician. We share a mutual idol -- "Six Crises" sounds like a page from Churchill.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Churchill, DeGaulle, Disraeli.  They all went through the pain of losing power.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: But they all got it back again, didn't they?  We should have lunch sometime.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: Well, as you know, most of my staff have weighed in against this "incursion."  They believe it will fail to achieve anything fundamental militarily, and will result in crushing criticism domestically ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I didn't ask what your staff thinks, Henry.  What do you think?

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: What I think is ... they're cowards. Their opposition represents the cowardice of the Eastern Establishment.  They don't realize as you do, Mr. President, that the Communists only respect strength, and they will only negotiate in good faith if they fear the "madman," Richard Nixon.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: Exactly, sir.  That is your historical contribution: to lead boldly in an era of limits.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: No one understands! -- even my own men.  What do you think the Communists respond to?  Honesty, liberal guilt, soul-wringing crap, fathers on TV crying?  Hell no!  I understand the Communist mind, I've studied it for thirty years.  They grasp "realpolitik" better than any of us, right, Henry?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: That's triangular diplomacy, gentlemen.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: Exactly, yes, Mr. President.  That is my contention.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: That's what geopolitics is about -- the whole world linked by self interest ... You tell me, Ron, how the hell I can explain that on television to a bunch of simple-minded reporters and weeping fucking mothers!

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: This will get me a second term.  Damn it, without risk, there's no heroism. There's no history.  I, Nixon, was born to do this.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: Mr. President, this cannot be breathed!  Especially to our secretary of state -- that cretin Rogers ... The Chinese would never trust us again. The only way, I emphasize only way, to pull this off is in secret.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: This is a major coup, gentlemen -- our own State Department doesn't even know.  And if it leaks out of here tonight ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: That's right!  And if necessary, I'll drop the big one.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: We have to entertain the possibility ...

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: You'll pick up the middle on this one - the Jews and Negros.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Jews and Negros don't win elections, Henry.  Better to hang them around the Democrats' necks.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Housecleaning?  It would be ugly, Henry, really ugly ...

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: But it must be done; your government is paralyzed.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: All kinds of shit would come out. Like the Ellsberg thing.  You knew about that, Henry, didn't you?

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: I ... I heard something ... It sounded idiotic.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Idiotic?  Yes, I suppose it was.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: That doesn't matter now, Henry.  The point is, you might lose some of your media-darling halo if the press starts sniffing around our dirty laundry.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: I had nothing to do with that, sir, and I resent any implication ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Resent it all you want, Henry, but you're in it with the rest of us. Cambodia, Ellsberg, the wiretaps you put in.  The President wants you to know you can't just click your heels and head back to Harvard Yard.  It's your ass too, Henry, and it's in the wind twisting with everyone else's.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: Mr. Nixon, it is possible for even a president to go too far.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yeah ...

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: Can you imagine what this man would have been had he ever been loved?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: ... because people have got to know whether or not their President is a crook.  Well, I am not a crook.  I have never made a dime from public service ...

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: Oh God, I'm going to throw up.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yes, you always had a good sense of timing, Henry.  When to give and when to take. How do you think Mao, Brezhnev will react?  Do you think this is how they'll remember me, Henry, after all the great things you and I did together? As some kind of ... of ... crooks?

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: They will understand, sir.  To be undone by a third-rate burglary is a fate of biblical proportions.  History will treat you far more kindly than your contemporaries.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: That depends who writes the history books.  I'm not a quitter ... but I'm not stupid either ... A trial would kill me -- that's what they want.  But they won't get it.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: If they harass you, I, too, will resign.  And I will tell the world why.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Don't be stupid.  The world needs you, Henry; you always saw the big picture. You were my equal in many ways.  You're the only friend I've got, Henry.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: You have many friends ... and admirers ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Do you ever pray?  You know ... believe in a Supreme Being?

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: Uh ... not really.  You mean on my knees?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yes.  My mother used to pray ... a lot.  It's been a long time since I really prayed.  Let's pray, Henry; let's pray a little.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: ... Uh, I hope this doesn't embarrass you.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: Not at all.  This is not going to leak, is it?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Don't be too proud; never be too proud to go on your knees before God.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: You know, Mr. Chairman, at Harvard I used your writings in my class.

turns.speaker: MAO
turns.text: What a waste of time.  My writings mean absolutely nothing.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: But your writings have changed the world, Mr. Chairman.

turns.speaker: MAO
turns.text: Fung pi!   I've only managed to change a few things around the city of Beijing.  I want to know your secret.

turns.speaker: KISSINGER
turns.text: Secret, Mr. Chairman?

turns.speaker: MAO
turns.text: How a fat man gets so many girls.

turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: I was asleep, Mr. President.  What can I get you?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Just ... uh ... you know.

turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Do you miss Cuba, Manolo?

turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: Yes, Mr. President.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: We let you down, didn't we.  Your people.

turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: That was Mr. Kennedy.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You don't think he was a hero?

turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: He was a politician.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Did you cry when he died?

turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MANOLO
turns.text: I don't know.  He made me see the stars ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: How did he do that?  All those kids ... Why do they hate me so much?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I must say you look very good, Mr. Chairman.

turns.speaker: MAO
turns.text: Looks can be deceiving ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: We know you've taken a great risk in inviting us here.

turns.speaker: MAO
turns.text: Don't ever trust them.  They never tell the truth or honor their commitments.  Vietnamese are like Russians.  Both are dogs.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Mr. Chairman, there is an old saying: The enemy of my enemy is my friend.

turns.speaker: MAO
turns.text: That has the added virtue of being true.

turns.speaker: MAO
turns.text: You know, I voted for you in your last election.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I was the lesser of two evils.

turns.speaker: MAO
turns.text: You're too modest, Nixon.  You're as evil as I am.  We're both from poor families.  But others pay to feed the hunger in us.  In my case, millions of reactionaries.  In your case, millions of Vietnamese.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Civil war is always the cruelest kind of war.

turns.speaker: MAO
turns.text: The real war is in us.  History is a symptom of our disease.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yes, well ... Gentlemen, I promised my wife.  I'm out of politics.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: You just came down here for the weather, right, Mr. Nixon?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I came down here to close a deal for Studebaker.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: So ... how's the food over there in China, Mr. Nixon?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Free, if you're the president.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: What are you going to do about this Allende fellow nationalizing our businesses in Chile?  You gonna send Kissinger down there?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: We're gonna get rid of him -- Allende, I mean -- just as fast as we can. He's on the top of the list.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: How about Kissinger along with him?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Kissinger's misunderstood.  He pretends to be a liberal for his Establishment friends, but he's even tougher than I am ...

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: We can prosecute the New York Times, go for an injunction ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: ... but it's not, bottom-line, gonna change a goddamn thing, John.  The question is: How do we screw Ellsberg so bad it puts the fear of God into all leakers?
